title: üö≤ How Does a Bike-Share Navigate Speedy Success?
text:
üöß This case study is currently under construction.
Please check back soon for a complete walkthrough, analysis, and visualizations.

title: üö≤ How Does a Bike-Share Navigate Speedy Success?
text:
üìö Project Context
This project satisfies the requirements of the Google Data Analytics capstone while also serving as a portfolio piece demonstrating:

Independent sourcing and integration of multi-year real-world data
Use of tools beyond the course scope (e.g., SQLite, Leaflet, Tableau, shell scripting)
Realistic data cleaning, transformation, and exploratory analysis

The fictional business challenge of Cyclistic is explored through the lens of actual Divvy usage patterns.

title: üö≤ How Does a Bike-Share Navigate Speedy Success?
text:
üéØ Business Task
How do casual riders and annual members use Divvy bikes differently, and how can that inform marketing strategies?

title: üö≤ How Does a Bike-Share Navigate Speedy Success?
Visualizations
text:
](Top_50_Stations_by_User_Type.html){target=‚Äú_blank‚Äù}

This interactive map of the top 50 stations includes the top 50 stations by number of subscriber rides and the top 50 stations by number of customer rides. We follow the normal color scheme with the dots for subscriber stations rendered in darkblue and the dots for customer stations rendered in darkorance. The dots for stations are offset slightly to avoid one dot obscuring the other for the cases where the station is in the top 50 for both subscribers and customers. This is accomplished by using a data frame where the location of the stations is offset. The size of the dots is scaled by the total number of rides (subscriber or customer as appropriate), so that stations with more rides are larger dots.
It was created in R using Leaflet with the following command
leaflet(top_stations_df_offset) %>%
     addTiles() %>%
     addCircleMarkers(
         lng = ~long_offset,
         lat = ~lat,
         color = ~pal(user_type),
         radius = ~pmax(sqrt(ride_count) / 50, 4),
         stroke = FALSE,
         fillOpacity = 0.8,
         popup = ~paste0(
             "<b>", name, "</b><br>", "Rank: #", rn, "<br>",
             "User Type: ", user_type, "<br>",
             "Ride Count: ", format(ride_count, big.mark = ",")
         )
     ) %>%
     addLegend(
         position = "bottomright",
         pal = pal,
         values = ~user_type,
         title = "User Type",
         opacity = 1
     )
Tableau dashboard

This interactive map of the top 50 stations includes the top 50 stations by number of subscriber rides and the top 50 stations by number of customer rides. The size of the dots is scaled by the total number of rides (subscriber or customer as appropriate), so that stations with more rides are larger dots.
It was created in R using Leaflet with the following command
leaflet(top_stations_df_offset) %>%
     addTiles() %>%
